name: Kepler-112
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-112 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-112 is a star with 0.7350000000000001 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.84 times its radius. It is located 1698.95 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-112 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-112 b

Kepler-112 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 8.41 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-112.

The mass of Kepler-112 b is 7.59 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-112 b is 2.36 that of Earth. At 7.59 Earth masses, Kepler-112 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-112 c

Kepler-112 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.17 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 28.57 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-112.

The mass of Kepler-112 c is 7.86 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-112 c is 2.4 that of Earth. At 7.86 Earth masses, Kepler-112 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-112, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
